title: EU citizens and 16-year-olds will not be allowed to vote in December election
text:
Lindsay Hoyle, the Deputy Speaker of the House of Commons (Picture: PA)

Opposition parties have failed in their bid to allow 16 and 17-year-olds as well as EU citizens with settled statuses to vote in any upcoming election.

The SNP, Labour and Liberal Democrats were hoping that amendments which had been proposed to extend the franchise would be selected.

However, Deputy Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle has selected Labour’s amendment for a general election on Monday December 9 and an associated technical amendment.

The provisional grouping and selection of amendments document shows Sir Lindsay has not selected amendments for votes at 16 nor to extend the franchise to allow EU nationals living in the UK to take part.

The government had earlier threatened to pull the election Bill, if the amendments to give 16 and 17-year-olds or EU citizens with settled status the right to vote, passed.

However, Boris Johnson’s plans for a pre-Christmas general election have now cleared their first Commons hurdle.

The Prime Minister wants to go to the polls on December 12 – declaring the need for a ‘new and revitalised’ Parliament which is able to deliver Brexit.

Downing Street had threatened to pull the election bill if the amendments passed (Picture: PA)

MPs backed his Early Parliamentary General Election Bill at second reading without a formal vote early on Tuesday evening.

Commons Speaker John Bercow said a clear an ‘overwhelming majority’ of parliamentarians were in support of the legislation at second reading.

But MPs could seek to amend the Bill as it undergoes further scrutiny in the Commons later on Tuesday.

Labour Leader Jeremy Corbyn had backed plans to give 16 and 17-year-olds as well as EU citizens with settled statuses to vote in the proposed December election (Picture: Reuters/UK Pool)

They may vote to move the election to Monday December 9, after Deputy Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle selected the Labour amendment seeking to change the date.

But the Government is understood to be opposed to bringing the proposed polling date forward by three days, and sees the amendment as an attempt to scupper an election.

The Prime Minister’s official spokesman said earlier on Tuesday that a December 9 poll would not be ‘logistically possible’.
